title: Endurance Training and Life Lessons
content: Ultra-endurance athlete and entrepreneur discusses the lessons he’s learned from his remarkable athletic feats, and the training required to reach them. His advice is practical for those looking to take their endurance training to the next level, but his lessons and insight are extraordinarily applicable to living everyday life.

title: Mindset, Nutrition, and Fasting for Training
content: Mindset, nutrition, fasting, and other advice for those looking to take the next step in their training. What getting a parasite taught about fasting.

title: Endurance Training and Nutrition
content: Ultra-endurance athlete and entrepreneur, Mike Trevino, discusses the lessons he’s learned from his remarkable athletic feats, and the training required to reach them. Mike’s advice is practical for those looking to take their endurance training to the next level. His nutritional strategy during runs include zero calories, some Crystal Light packets, and $20 for emergency banana, if necessary. To do this on zero calories, Mike is extremely fat-adapted, he’s likely spending 600-700 kilojoules per hour and if not fat-adapted you’d be done after 2-3 hours relying on glucose alone.

title: The Risks Involved with Cycling
content: Discussion on the risks involved with cycling.

title: Performance Enhancing Drugs and Stimulants
content: Discussion on performance enhancing drugs (PEDs), stimulants, and their effect on performance.

title: Life-Lessons Learned from Training
content: Discussion on life-lessons learned from training, and how to impart them to his kids, and others.

title: Race Across America (RAAM), Perseverance, and Extreme Sleep Deprivation
content: RAAM, the single most challenging cycling event, is a 3,000 mile transcontinental, non-stop cycling race from east to west coast. It is not just the rider, but logistics, your crew of people, race rules, multifaceted, must engineer the race well, food, bike equipment, several cars following, part of the fun. Very hard on the crews who sometimes blow up and “world class riders drop out before Arizona”.

title: Sleep Deprivation and Performance
content: The normal daily strategy that people take is on the bike for 20-22 hours, and sleep for 2-4 hours. But one participant only slept around 10.5 hours over the 8 days. At one point, the lack of sleep starting causing hallucinations. Sleep, it was found, is more important than food and hydration when it comes to thermoregulation, muscle glycogen restoration, synapse repair and formation.

title: Importance of REM Sleep Cycle in Performance
content: Two things that will determine if you can win a race: What is your speed after you’ve depleted muscle glycogen and you’re just cruising: your “all-day” speed. What’s your REM sleep cycle? So one would have someone watch their eye patterns while they slept and then wake them up immediately following their REM cycle: if you are woken up during REM you will feel sleepy — if your REM cycles were only 90 minutes, as opposed to say 2.5 hours, you could win the race.

title: Nutrition and Fasting for Performance
content: If you are an ultra distance athlete you HAVE to be fat adapted. Despite the common practice of carb-loading for long endurance events, one participant never felt good after carb loading: bloated, HR not good the next day. Experimented with fat for energy, like coconut oil. Started to notice that he could actually feel and perform better when fasted. Started to phase things out: carbs, alcohol.

title: Fasting for Health
content: In 2002, one participant spent some time in Tibet, the Himalayas, he was on Everest for a couple months and they were eating Yak meat, which you can’t cook in altitude, so when he came back in 2003, he had parasites. Doctor gave him meds, but also told him that historically our ancestors would fast to deal with parasites. He did a 10-day fast, combined with the meditation, only drank warm water. Not only did it fix his parasite problem, he was also developing exercise-induced asthma, became allergic to certain foods, and all this went away in 2003, by fasting.

title: Risks Involved with Cycling
content: Just like mountain climbers attempting Everest and K2 have a risk of death, cycling too, comes with serious risk. Both experienced cyclists died in cycling accidents. One participant doesn’t ride as much now that he has family.

title: Performance Enhancing Drugs and Stimulants
content: For one participant, endurance competitions were a sacred endeavor, he was never interested in using performance-enhancing drugs (PEDs). Stimulants can add an advantage, but you better know when to use them, and for how long, because you can fall off a cliff pretty quickly.

title: Motivation and Sacrifice in Extreme Sports
content: For one participant, it really all started because he was “running away from stuff”. People always ask, what do you think about when you’re out there for so long? Do you get bored? “No, it’s very meditative for me”. A time to think and work through stuff past and present. People ask, is it worth the sacrifice? He calls it a privilege, “if it was a sacrifice, I wouldn’t do it”.

title: Nutrition and Lifestyle
content: Nutrition and lifestyle is mostly what I try to impart, you don’t need to carb-load.

title: Train Smart
content: Be intelligent about when to push and when to back down. The best approach is a cross-functional world-class expert team. You think outside the box and bring in other ideas from other domains.

title: General Rules for Success
content: Don’t limit yourself to thinking about just the marathon (or whatever you’re attempting to do), look at yourself, be objective, and think about what it’s going to take to achieve what you define as success. Don’t be afraid to ask questions. Don’t overthink it (data is good, but unless breaking a world record, just go out and have fun).
